title: Generalized Ellipsoids
text: gellipsoid package extends class geometric ellipsoids ‚Äúgeneralized ellipsoids‚Äù, allow degenerate ellipsoids flat /unbounded. Thus, ellipsoids can naturally defined include lines, hyperplanes, points, cylinders, etc. methods can used represent generalized ellipsoids dd-dimensional space ùêëd\mathbf{R}^d, plots 3D. goal able think , visualize, compute linear transformation ellipsoid central matrix ùêÇ\mathbf{C} inverse ùêÇ‚àí1\mathbf{C}^{-1} apply equally unbounded /degenerate ellipsoids. permits exploration variety statistical issues can visualized using ellipsoids discussed Friendly, Fox & Monette (2013), Elliptical Insights: Understanding Statistical Methods Elliptical Geometry doi:10.1214/12-STS402. implementation uses (ùêî,ùêÉ)(\mathbf{U}, \mathbf{D}) representation, based singular value decomposition (SVD) ellipsoid-generating matrix, ùêÄ=ùêîùêÉùêïT\mathbf{} = \mathbf{U} \mathbf{D} \mathbf{V}^{T}, ùêî\mathbf{U} square orthogonal ùêÉ\mathbf{D} diagonal. usual, ‚Äúproper‚Äù ellipsoids, ùêÄ\mathbf{} positive-definite elements ùêÉ\mathbf{D} positive. generalized ellipsoids, ùêÉ\mathbf{D} extended non-negative real numbers, .e.¬† elements can 0, Inf positive real.

title: Generalized Ellipsoids
text: proper ellipsoid ùêëd\mathbf{R}^d can defined ùêÑ:={x:xTùêÇx‚â§1}\mathbf{E} := \{x \; : \; x^T \mathbf{C} x \le 1 \} ùêÇ\mathbf{C} non-negative definite central matrix, applications, ùêÇ\mathbf{C} typically variance-covariance matrix proper ellipsoid bounded, non-empty interior. call fat ellipsoids. degenerate flat ellipsoid corresponds one central matrix ùêÇ\mathbf{C} singular one zero singular values ùêÉ\mathbf{D}. 3D, generalized ellipsoid flat one dimension (ùêÉ=diag{X,X,0}\mathbf{D} = \mathrm{diag} \{X, X, 0\}) collapses ellipse; one flat two dimensions (ùêÉ=diag{X,0,0}\mathbf{D} = \mathrm{diag} \{X, 0, 0\}) collapses line, one flat three dimensions collapses point. unbounded ellipsoid one infinite extent one directions, characterized infinite singular values ùêÉ\mathbf{D}. example, 3D, unbounded ellipsoid one infinite singular value infinite cylinder elliptical cross-section.

title: Generalized Ellipsoids
text: gell() Constructs generalized ellipsoid using (ùêî,ùêÉ)(\mathbf{U}, \mathbf{D}) representation. inputs can specified variety ways: non-negative definite variance matrix; inner-product matrix subspace given span matrix giving linear transformation unit sphere dual() calculates dual inverse generalized ellipsoid gmult() calculates linear transformation generalized ellipsoid signature() calculates signature generalized ellipsoid, vector length 3 giving number positive, zero infinite singular values (U, D) representation. ell3d() Plots generalized ellipsoids 3D using rgl package

title: Generalized Ellipsoids
text: can install gellipsoid package CRAN follows: , can install development version gellipsoid GitHub :
code: install.packages("gellipsoid") # install.packages("remotes") remotes::install_github("friendly/gellipsoid")

title: Generalized Ellipsoids
text: following examples illustrate gell objects properties. may plotted 3D using ell3d(). objects can specified variety ways, examples span simplest. unit sphere R3R^3 central matrix identity matrix. plane R3R^3 flat one dimension. hyperplane. Note gell object center contains information geometric plane. point:
code: library(gellipsoid) (zsph <- gell(Sigma = diag(3)))  # a unit sphere in R^3 #> $center #> [1] 0 0 0 #>  #> $u #>      [,1] [,2] [,3] #> [1,]    0    0    1 #> [2,]    0    1    0 #> [3,]    1    0    0 #>  #> $d #> [1] 1 1 1 #>  #> attr(,"class") #> [1] "gell" signature(zsph) #>  pos zero  inf  #>    3    0    0 isBounded(zsph) #> [1] TRUE isFlat(zsph) #> [1] FALSE (zplane <- gell(span = diag(3)[, 1:2]))  # a plane #> $center #> [1] 0 0 0 #>  #> $u #>      [,1] [,2] [,3] #> [1,]    1    0    0 #> [2,]    0    1    0 #> [3,]    0    0    1 #>  #> $d #> [1] Inf Inf   0 #>  #> attr(,"class") #> [1] "gell" signature(zplane) #>  pos zero  inf  #>    0    1    2 isBounded(zplane) #> [1] FALSE isFlat(zplane) #> [1] TRUE  dual(zplane)  # line orthogonal to that plane #> $center #> [1] 0 0 0 #>  #> $u #>      [,1] [,2] [,3] #> [1,]    0    0    1 #> [2,]    0    1    0 #> [3,]    1    0    0 #>  #> $d #> [1] Inf   0   0 #>  #> attr(,"class") #> [1] "gell" signature(dual(zplane)) #>  pos zero  inf  #>    0    2    1 (zhplane <- gell(center = c(0, 0, 2),                   span = diag(3)[, 1:2]))  # a hyperplane #> $center #> [1] 0 0 2 #>  #> $u #>      [,1] [,2] [,3] #> [1,]    1    0    0 #> [2,]    0    1    0 #> [3,]    0    0    1 #>  #> $d #> [1] Inf Inf   0 #>  #> attr(,"class") #> [1] "gell" signature(zhplane) #>  pos zero  inf  #>    0    1    2  dual(zhplane)  # orthogonal line through same center #> $center #> [1] 0 0 2 #>  #> $u #>      [,1] [,2] [,3] #> [1,]    0    0    1 #> [2,]    0    1    0 #> [3,]    1    0    0 #>  #> $d #> [1] Inf   0   0 #>  #> attr(,"class") #> [1] "gell" zorigin <- gell(span = cbind(c(0, 0, 0))) signature(zorigin) #>  pos zero  inf  #>    0    3    0  # what is the dual (inverse) of a point? dual(zorigin) #> $center #> [1] 0 0 0 #>  #> $u #>      [,1] [,2] [,3] #> [1,]    0    0    1 #> [2,]    0    1    0 #> [3,]    1    0    0 #>  #> $d #> [1] Inf Inf Inf #>  #> attr(,"class") #> [1] "gell"  signature(dual(zorigin)) #>  pos zero  inf  #>    0    0    3

title: Generalized Ellipsoids
text: following figure shows views two generalized ellipsoids. C1C_1 (blue) determines proper, fat ellipsoid; ‚Äôs inverse C1‚àí1C_1^{-1} also generates proper ellipsoid. C2C_2 (red) determines improper, flat ellipsoid, whose inverse C2‚àí1C_2^{-1} unbounded cylinder elliptical cross-section. C2C_2 projection C1C_1 onto plane z=0z = 0. scale ellipsoids defined gray unit sphere.  figure illustrates orthogonality CC dual, C‚àí1C^{-1}.

title: Generalized Ellipsoids
text: Friendly, M., Monette, G. Fox, J. (2013). Elliptical Insights: Understanding Statistical Methods Elliptical Geometry. Statistical Science, 28(1), 1‚Äì39. Online paper; DOI Friendly, M. (2013). Supplementary materials ‚ÄúElliptical Insights ‚Ä¶‚Äù, https://www.datavis.ca/papers/ellipses/

what: Draw Basis Vectors in an rgl Scene ‚Äî basis3d
title: Draw Basis Vectors in an rgl Scene ‚Äî basis3d
text: function calculates optionally draws basis vectors used coordinate axes rgl 3D display.  geometric diagrams data displays, can useful using axis3d box3d provide guides axes.  origin argument permits multiple diagrams graphs display, coordinate axes.

title: Draw Basis Vectors in an rgl Scene ‚Äî basis3d
code: basis3d(   matrix = diag(3),   origin = c(0, 0, 0),   scale = 1,   draw = TRUE,   label = draw,   texts = colnames(basis),   lwd = 3,   cex = 2,   ... )

title: Draw Basis Vectors in an rgl Scene ‚Äî basis3d
text: matrix 3 x 3 matrix, whose columns basis vectors, typically unit length. origin Origin rgl scene basis vectors scale Scaling factor basis vectors draw TRUE, vectors plotted label TRUE, vectors labeled tips texts character vector length 3 used labels. Defaults c("x", "y", "z"). lwd Line width vectors cex Character size labels ... arguments, passed segments3d text3d

title: Draw Basis Vectors in an rgl Scene ‚Äî basis3d
text: Returns invisibly 6 x 3 matrix, whose columns coordinate axes, c("x", "y", "z").  Odd numbered rows give coordinates origin, even numbered rows give locations tips vectors.

title: Draw Basis Vectors in an rgl Scene ‚Äî basis3d
text: Michael Friendly

title: Draw Basis Vectors in an rgl Scene ‚Äî basis3d
code: # show two different sets of basis vectors open3d() basis3d() A <- matrix(c(1,2,0.1,               2,1,0.1,               0.1,0.1,0.5), 3,3) basis3d(t(A), col="red")  # scene with two different displays open3d() basis3d() basis3d(origin=c(2,0,0))

what: Find the bounding box of a rgl::mesh3d or rgl::qmesh3d object ‚Äî bbox3d
title: Find the bounding box of a rgl::mesh3d or rgl::qmesh3d object ‚Äî bbox3d
text: Ellipsoids created rgl functions meshes points, segments, ... coordinates various forms. function calculates bounding box, defined range x, y, z coordinates.

title: Find the bounding box of a rgl::mesh3d or rgl::qmesh3d object ‚Äî bbox3d
code: bbox3d(x, ...)

title: Find the bounding box of a rgl::mesh3d or rgl::qmesh3d object ‚Äî bbox3d
text: x mesh3d object ... ignored

title: Find the bounding box of a rgl::mesh3d or rgl::qmesh3d object ‚Äî bbox3d
text: 2 x 3 matrix, giving minimum maximum values rows x, y, z coordinates             columns.

what: Dual or 'Inverse' of an ellipsoid ‚Äî dual
title: Dual or 'Inverse' of an ellipsoid ‚Äî dual
text: dual produces orthogonal complement subspaces ellipsoids. equivalent inverting \(\Sigma\) inner product ip non-singular.

title: Dual or 'Inverse' of an ellipsoid ‚Äî dual
code: dual(x, ...)  # S3 method for class 'gell' dual(x, ...)

title: Dual or 'Inverse' of an ellipsoid ‚Äî dual
text: x object, class "gell" ... arguments, unused now.

title: Dual or 'Inverse' of an ellipsoid ‚Äî dual
text: (U, D) representation dual, components  LIST, use u Right singular vectors d Singular values

title: Dual or 'Inverse' of an ellipsoid ‚Äî dual
text: present, dual defined objects class "gell". (U,D) representation, dual simply columns U reverse order, reciprocals diagonal elements D, also reverse order.

title: Dual or 'Inverse' of an ellipsoid ‚Äî dual
text: Dempster, . (1969). Elements Continuous Multivariate Analysis Reading, MA: Addison-Wesley.

title: Dual or 'Inverse' of an ellipsoid ‚Äî dual
text: Georges Monette

title: Dual or 'Inverse' of an ellipsoid ‚Äî dual
code: (zplane <- gell(span = diag(3)[,1:2]))  # a plane #> $center #> [1] 0 0 0 #>  #> $u #>      [,1] [,2] [,3] #> [1,]    1    0    0 #> [2,]    0    1    0 #> [3,]    0    0    1 #>  #> $d #> [1] Inf Inf   0 #>  #> attr(,"class") #> [1] "gell"  dual(zplane)  # line orthogonal to that plane #> $center #> [1] 0 0 0 #>  #> $u #>      [,1] [,2] [,3] #> [1,]    0    0    1 #> [2,]    0    1    0 #> [3,]    1    0    0 #>  #> $d #> [1] Inf   0   0 #>  #> attr(,"class") #> [1] "gell"  (zhplane <- gell(center = c(0,0,2), span = diag(3)[,1:2]))  # a hyperplane #> $center #> [1] 0 0 2 #>  #> $u #>      [,1] [,2] [,3] #> [1,]    1    0    0 #> [2,]    0    1    0 #> [3,]    0    0    1 #>  #> $d #> [1] Inf Inf   0 #>  #> attr(,"class") #> [1] "gell"  dual(zhplane) # orthogonal line through same center (note that the 'gell' #> $center #> [1] 0 0 2 #>  #> $u #>      [,1] [,2] [,3] #> [1,]    0    0    1 #> [2,]    0    1    0 #> [3,]    1    0    0 #>  #> $d #> [1] Inf   0   0 #>  #> attr(,"class") #> [1] "gell"               # object with a center contains more information than the geometric plane)  zorigin <- gell(span = cbind(c(0,0,0))) dual( zorigin ) #> $center #> [1] 0 0 0 #>  #> $u #>      [,1] [,2] [,3] #> [1,]    0    0    1 #> [2,]    0    1    0 #> [3,]    1    0    0 #>  #> $d #> [1] Inf Inf Inf #>  #> attr(,"class") #> [1] "gell"

what: Plot Generalized Ellipsoids in 3D using rgl ‚Äî ell3d
title: Plot Generalized Ellipsoids in 3D using rgl ‚Äî ell3d
text: ell3d convenience wrapper ellipsoid specialized class "gell" objects. plots ellipsoid current rgl window.

title: Plot Generalized Ellipsoids in 3D using rgl ‚Äî ell3d
code: ell3d(x, ...)  # Default S3 method ell3d(x, shape, radius = 1, segments = 40, shade = TRUE, wire = FALSE, ...)  # S3 method for class 'gell' ell3d(   x,   length = 10,   sides = 30,   segments = 40,   shade = TRUE,   wire = FALSE,   ... )

title: Plot Generalized Ellipsoids in 3D using rgl ‚Äî ell3d
text: x vector length 3 giving center ellipsoid default method, class "gell" object gell method. ... arguments, passed ellipsoid shape 3 x 3 symmetric matrix giving shape ellipsoid. radius radius ellipsoid segments number segments direction calculating mesh3d object shade Logical. Whether 3D ellipsoid shaded wire Logical. Whether 3D ellipsoid rendered wire frame length unbounded, (infinite) ellipsoids, length display infinite dimensions sides unbounded, cylindrical ellipsoids, number sides elliptical cross sections

title: Plot Generalized Ellipsoids in 3D using rgl ‚Äî ell3d
text: Returns result call ellipsoid

title: Plot Generalized Ellipsoids in 3D using rgl ‚Äî ell3d
text: implementation subject change.

title: Plot Generalized Ellipsoids in 3D using rgl ‚Äî ell3d
text: Georges Monette

title: Plot Generalized Ellipsoids in 3D using rgl ‚Äî ell3d
code: # a proper ellipsoid, and its inverse c1 <- c(0,0,0) C1 <- matrix(c(6, 2, 1,                2, 3, 2,                1, 2, 2), 3,3)  open3d() zell1 <- gell(center=c1, Sigma=C1) E1 <- ell3d(zell1, col="blue", alpha=0.1) # inverse of C1 E1I <- ell3d(dual(zell1), col="blue", alpha=0.1, wire=TRUE)  #open3d()  ## to see this in a new window # a singular ellipsoid and its inverse c2 <- c1 C2 <- matrix(c(6, 2, 0,                2, 3, 0,                0, 0, 0), 3,3)  E2 <- ell3d( zell2 <-gell( center = c2, Sigma = C2),               col = 'red', alpha = 0.25, wire = TRUE) E2I <- ell3d( dual(gell( center = c2, Sigma = C2)),               length=3, col = 'red', alpha = 0.25, wire = TRUE )  # signatures signature(zell1) #>  pos zero  inf  #>    3    0    0  signature(zell2) #>  pos zero  inf  #>    2    1    0

title: Calculate an ellipsoid in 3D ‚Äî ellipsoid
text: Calculates qmesh3d object representing 3D ellipsoid given center shape matrix.  function allows degenerate ellipsoids shape matrix rank < 3 plots ellipse line.

title: Calculate an ellipsoid in 3D ‚Äî ellipsoid
code: ellipsoid(center, shape, radius = 1, segments = 60, warn.rank = FALSE)

title: Calculate an ellipsoid in 3D ‚Äî ellipsoid
text: center vector length 3 giving center 3D ellipsoid, typically mean vector data matrix. shape 3 x 3 matrix giving shape 3D ellipsoid, typical covariance matrix data matrix. radius radius ellipsoid, default radius=1, giving standard ellipsoid. multivariate sample dfe degrees freedom associated shape, ellipsoid level coverage can calculated using radius=sqrt(3 * qf(level, 3, dfe)). segments number line segments use direction wire-frame representation ellipsoid warn.rank warn shape matrix rank < 3?

title: Calculate an ellipsoid in 3D ‚Äî ellipsoid
text: qmesh3d object

title: Calculate an ellipsoid in 3D ‚Äî ellipsoid
text: ellipsoid calculated transforming unit sphere Cholesky square root shape matrix, translating center. ellipsoid can plotted plot3d

what: (U, D) Representation of an Ellipsoid in R^p. ‚Äî gell
title: (U, D) Representation of an Ellipsoid in R^p. ‚Äî gell
text: gell provides set ways specify generalized ellipsoid \(R^p\), using (U, D) representation include special cases, U square orthogonal matrix, D diagonal extended non-negative real numbers, .e. 0, Inf positive real.

title: (U, D) Representation of an Ellipsoid in R^p. ‚Äî gell
code: gell(x, ...)  # Default S3 method gell(x, center = 0, Sigma, ip, span, A, u, d = 1, epsfac = 2, ...)  # S3 method for class 'gell' gell(x, ...)

title: (U, D) Representation of an Ellipsoid in R^p. ‚Äî gell
text: x object ... arguments center vector specifying center ellipsoid Sigma square, symmetric, non-negative definite dispersion (variance) matrix ip square, symmetric, non-negative definite inner product matrix. See Details. span subspace given span.  See Details. matrix giving linear transformation unit sphere. u U matrix d Diagonal elements D matrix epsfac Factor .Machine$double.eps used distinguish zero vs. positive singular values

title: (U, D) Representation of an Ellipsoid in R^p. ‚Äî gell
text: (U, D) representation ellipsoid, components center center u Right singular vectors d Singular values

title: (U, D) Representation of an Ellipsoid in R^p. ‚Äî gell
text: resulting class ellipsoids includes degenerate ellipsoids flat /unbounded. Thus ellipsoids naturally defined include lines, hyperplanes, points, cylinders, etc. gell can currently generate (U, D) representation 5 ways specifying ellipsoid: non-negative definite dispersion (variance) matrix, \(Sigma: U D^2 U' = Sigma\), elements diagonal matrix D can 0. can generate bounded ellipsoids, possibly flat. non-negative definite inner product matrix \('ip': U W^2 U = C\) elements diagonal matrix W can 0. set D = W^-1 0^-1 = Inf. can generate fat (non-empty interior) ellipsoids, possibly unbounded. subspace spanned 'span' Let U_1 orthonormal basis Span('span'), let U_2 orthonormal basis orthogonal complement, \(U = [ U_1 U_2 ]\) \(D = diag( c(Inf,...,Inf, 0,..,0))\) number Inf's equal number columns U_1. transformation unit sphere given (Unit sphere) = UDV', .e. SVD. (Generalization 4): , d matrix d vector factors corresponding columns . factors can 0, positive Inf. case U D U D(Unit sphere) = diag(d)(Unit sphere). representation can used forms ellipsoids ellipsoid can represented.

title: (U, D) Representation of an Ellipsoid in R^p. ‚Äî gell
text: Friendly, M., Monette, G. Fox, J. (2013). Elliptical Insights: Understanding Statistical Methods Elliptical Geometry. Statistical Science, 28(1), 1-39.

title: (U, D) Representation of an Ellipsoid in R^p. ‚Äî gell
text: Georges Monette

title: (U, D) Representation of an Ellipsoid in R^p. ‚Äî gell
Generalized ellipsoids ‚Äî gellipsoid-package
text: Represents generalized ellipsoids "(U,D)" representation, allowing degenerate unbounded ellipsoids, together methods linear duality transformations, plotting. permits exploration variety statistical issues can visualized using ellipsoids discussed Friendly, Fox & Monette (2013), "Elliptical Insights: Understanding Statistical Methods duality transformations, plotting. ideas described Friendly, Monette & Fox (2013) doi:10.1214/12-STS402 .

title: Generalized ellipsoids ‚Äî gellipsoid-package
text: uses (U, D) representation generalized ellipsoids \(R^d\), \(U\) square orthogonal \(D\) diagonal extended non-negative real numbers, .e. 0, Inf positive real). roughly analogous corresponding terms singular-value decomposition matrix, \(X = U D V'\). resulting class ellipsoids includes degenerate ellipsoids flat /unbounded. Thus ellipsoids naturally extended include lines, hyperplanes, points, cylinders, etc. class closed linear affine transformations (including spaces different dimensions) duality ('inverse') transformations. Unbounded ellipsoids, e.g. cylinders elliptical cross-sections, correspond singular inner products, .e. inner products defined singular inner product matrix. Flat ellipsoids correspond singular variances. corresponding inner product defined supporting subspace. Ellipsoids flat unbounded correspond lines, points, subspaces, hyperplanes, etc. gell can currently generate U-D representation 5 ways specifying ellipsoid: non-negative definite dispersion (variance) matrix, Sigma: \(U D^2 U' = \Sigma\), elements diagonal matrix D can 0. can generate bounded ellipsoids, possibly flat. non-negative definite inner product matrix 'ip': \(U W^2 U = C\) elements diagonal matrix W can 0. set D = W^-1 0^-1 = Inf. can generate fat (non-empty interior) ellipsoids, possibly unbounded. subspace spanned 'span' Let U_1 orthonormal basis Span('span'), let U_2 orthonormal basis orthogonal complement, U = [ U_1 U_2 ] D = diag( c(Inf,...,Inf, 0,..,0)) number Inf's equal number columns U_1. transformation unit sphere given (Unit sphere) \(= U D V'\), .e. SVD. (Generalization 4): (, d) matrix d vector factors corresponding columns . factors can 0, positive Inf. case U D U D(Unit sphere) = diag(d)(Unit sphere). representation can used forms ellipsoids ellipsoid can represented.

title: Generalized ellipsoids ‚Äî gellipsoid-package
text: Friendly, M., Monette, G. Fox, J. (2013). Elliptical Insights: Understanding Statistical Methods Elliptical Geometry. Statistical Science, 28(1), 1-39. Online: https://www.datavis.ca/papers/ellipses-STS402.pdf, DOI: doi:10.1214/12-STS402

title: Generalized ellipsoids ‚Äî gellipsoid-package
text: Georges Monette Michael Friendly Maintainer: Michael Friendly <friendly@yorku.ca>

title: Generalized ellipsoids ‚Äî gellipsoid-package
code: (zsph <- gell(Sigma = diag(3)))  # unit sphere in R^3 #> $center #> [1] 0 0 0 #>  #> $u #>      [,1] [,2] [,3] #> [1,]    0    0    1 #> [2,]    0    1    0 #> [3,]    1    0    0 #>  #> $d #> [1] 1 1 1 #>  #> attr(,"class") #> [1] "gell"  (zplane <- gell(span = diag(3)[, 1:2]))  # a plane #> $center #> [1] 0 0 0 #>  #> $u #>      [,1] [,2] [,3] #> [1,]    1    0    0 #> [2,]    0    1    0 #> [3,]    0    0    1 #>  #> $d #> [1] Inf Inf   0 #>  #> attr(,"class") #> [1] "gell"  dual(zplane)  # line orthogonal to that plane #> $center #> [1] 0 0 0 #>  #> $u #>      [,1] [,2] [,3] #> [1,]    0    0    1 #> [2,]    0    1    0 #> [3,]    1    0    0 #>  #> $d #> [1] Inf   0   0 #>  #> attr(,"class") #> [1] "gell"  (zhplane <- gell(center = c(0, 0, 2), span = diag(3)[, 1:2]))  # a hyperplane #> $center #> [1] 0 0 2 #>  #> $u #>      [,1] [,2] [,3] #> [1,]    1    0    0 #> [2,]    0    1    0 #> [3,]    0    0    1 #>  #> $d #> [1] Inf Inf   0 #>  #> attr(,"class") #> [1] "gell"  dual(zhplane)  # orthogonal line through same center (note that the 'gell' #> $center #> [1] 0 0 2 #>  #> $u #>      [,1] [,2] [,3] #> [1,]    0    0    1 #> [2,]    0    1    0 #> [3,]    1    0    0 #>  #> $d #> [1] Inf   0   0 #>  #> attr(,"class") #> [1] "gell" # object with a center contains more information than the geometric plane)  zorigin <- gell(span = cbind(c(0, 0, 0))) dual(zorigin) #> $center #> [1] 0 0 0 #>  #> $u #>      [,1] [,2] [,3] #> [1,]    0    0    1 #> [2,]    0    1    0 #> [3,]    1    0    0 #>  #> $d #> [1] Inf Inf Inf #>  #> attr(,"class") #> [1] "gell"  # signatures of these ellipsoids signature(zsph) #>  pos zero  inf  #>    3    0    0  signature(zhplane) #>  pos zero  inf  #>    0    1    2  signature(dual(zhplane)) #>  pos zero  inf  #>    0    2    1

what: Tests for Classes of Generalized Ellipsoids ‚Äî isBounded
title: Tests for Classes of Generalized Ellipsoids ‚Äî isBounded
text: functions provide tests classes generalized ellipsoids (U, D) representation, based numbers positive, zero infinite singular values D. included mainly computational definitions terms ‚Äòbounded‚Äô ellipsoid finite extent, ‚Äòfat‚Äô, bounded ellipsoid non-empty interior, ‚Äòflat‚Äô, degenerate (singular) ellipsoids \(R^p\) empty interior.

title: Tests for Classes of Generalized Ellipsoids ‚Äî isBounded
code: isBounded(x, ...)  # S3 method for class 'gell' isBounded(x, ...)  isFat(x, ...)  # S3 method for class 'gell' isFat(x, ...)  isFlat(x, ...)  # S3 method for class 'gell' isFlat(x, ...)  isUnbounded(x, ...)  # S3 method for class 'gell' isUnbounded(x, ...)

title: Tests for Classes of Generalized Ellipsoids ‚Äî isBounded
text: x class "gell" object ... arguments, used.

title: Tests for Classes of Generalized Ellipsoids ‚Äî isBounded
text: TRUE FALSE

title: Tests for Classes of Generalized Ellipsoids ‚Äî isBounded
text: Friendly, M., Monette, G. Fox, J. (2013). Elliptical Insights: Understanding Statistical Methods Elliptical Geometry. Statistical Science, 28(1), 1-39.

title: Tests for Classes of Generalized Ellipsoids ‚Äî isBounded

what: Save and Restore the par3d Parameters for an rgl Scene ‚Äî par3d.save
title: Save and Restore the par3d Parameters for an rgl Scene ‚Äî par3d.save
text: Use function make manually manipulated rgl view reproducible, within sessions across sessions. Within R session, simply use par3d.save record par3d parameters view(s) named objects. Across sessions, use filename argument save .rds files

title: Save and Restore the par3d Parameters for an rgl Scene ‚Äî par3d.save
code: par3d.save(   params = c("userMatrix", "scale", "zoom", "FOV"),   filename,   dev = rgl.cur() )  par3d.restore(parms, filename)

title: Save and Restore the par3d Parameters for an rgl Scene ‚Äî par3d.save
text: params list par3d parameters save filename Name .rds file save restore dev rgl device.  Currently unused parms list par3d parameters restore

title: Save and Restore the par3d Parameters for an rgl Scene ‚Äî par3d.save
text: par3d.save returns list current values par3d parameters named params.

title: Save and Restore the par3d Parameters for an rgl Scene ‚Äî par3d.save
text: Michael Friendly

title: Save and Restore the par3d Parameters for an rgl Scene ‚Äî par3d.save
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{   library(rgl)   open3d()   # ...   parms <- par3d.save()   # ....   par3d.restore(parms)    } # }

what: Signature of a Generalized Ellipsoid ‚Äî signature
title: Signature of a Generalized Ellipsoid ‚Äî signature
text: Calculates signature generalized ellipsoid, vector length 3 giving number positive, zero infinite singular values (U, D) representation

title: Signature of a Generalized Ellipsoid ‚Äî signature
code: signature(G)

title: Signature of a Generalized Ellipsoid ‚Äî signature
text: G class "gell" objects

title: Signature of a Generalized Ellipsoid ‚Äî signature
text: vector length 3, named components pos, zero            inf

title: Signature of a Generalized Ellipsoid ‚Äî signature
text: Friendly, M., Monette, G. Fox, J. (2013). Elliptical Insights: Understanding Statistical Methods Elliptical Geometry. Statistical Science, 28(1), 1-39.

title: Signature of a Generalized Ellipsoid ‚Äî signature
text: Georges Monette

title: Signature of a Generalized Ellipsoid ‚Äî signature
code: (zsph <- gell(Sigma = diag(3)))  # unit sphere in R^3 #> $center #> [1] 0 0 0 #>  #> $u #>      [,1] [,2] [,3] #> [1,]    0    0    1 #> [2,]    0    1    0 #> [3,]    1    0    0 #>  #> $d #> [1] 1 1 1 #>  #> attr(,"class") #> [1] "gell"  (zplane <- gell(span = diag(3)[,1:2]))  # a plane #> $center #> [1] 0 0 0 #>  #> $u #>      [,1] [,2] [,3] #> [1,]    1    0    0 #> [2,]    0    1    0 #> [3,]    0    0    1 #>  #> $d #> [1] Inf Inf   0 #>  #> attr(,"class") #> [1] "gell"  dual(zplane)  # line orthogonal to that plane #> $center #> [1] 0 0 0 #>  #> $u #>      [,1] [,2] [,3] #> [1,]    0    0    1 #> [2,]    0    1    0 #> [3,]    1    0    0 #>  #> $d #> [1] Inf   0   0 #>  #> attr(,"class") #> [1] "gell"  (zhplane <- gell(center = c(0,0,2), span = diag(3)[,1:2]))  # a hyperplane #> $center #> [1] 0 0 2 #>  #> $u #>      [,1] [,2] [,3] #> [1,]    1    0    0 #> [2,]    0    1    0 #> [3,]    0    0    1 #>  #> $d #> [1] Inf Inf   0 #>  #> attr(,"class") #> [1] "gell"  dual(zhplane) # orthogonal line through same center (note that the 'gell' #> $center #> [1] 0 0 2 #>  #> $u #>      [,1] [,2] [,3] #> [1,]    0    0    1 #> [2,]    0    1    0 #> [3,]    1    0    0 #>  #> $d #> [1] Inf   0   0 #>  #> attr(,"class") #> [1] "gell"               # object with a center contains more information than the geometric plane)  zorigin <- gell(span = cbind(c(0,0,0))) dual( zorigin ) #> $center #> [1] 0 0 0 #>  #> $u #>      [,1] [,2] [,3] #> [1,]    0    0    1 #> [2,]    0    1    0 #> [3,]    1    0    0 #>  #> $d #> [1] Inf Inf Inf #>  #> attr(,"class") #> [1] "gell"  # signatures of these ellipsoids signature(zsph) #>  pos zero  inf  #>    3    0    0  signature(zhplane) #>  pos zero  inf  #>    0    1    2  signature(dual(zhplane)) #>  pos zero  inf  #>    0    2    1
